body_text.text: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking
We present a search for associated production of Higgs and W bosons in pp collisions at a center of mass energy of √ s = 1.96 TeV in 5.3 fb −1 of integrated luminosity recorded by the D0 experiment.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: Multivariate analysis techniques are applied to events containing one lepton, an imbalance in transverse energy, and one or two b-tagged jets to discriminate a potential W H signal from Standard Model backgrounds.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: We observe good agreement between data and expected backgrounds, and set an upper limit of 4.5 (at 95% confidence level and for m H = 115 GeV) on the ratio of the W H cross section multiplied by the branching fraction of H → bb to its Standard Model prediction, which is consistent with an expected limit of 4.8.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: The only unobserved particle of the Standard Model (SM) is the Higgs boson (H ).
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: Its observation would support the hypothesis that the Higgs mechanism generates the masses of the weak gauge bosons and accommodates finite masses of fermions through their Yukawa couplings to the Higgs field.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: The mass of the Higgs boson (m H ) is not predicted by the SM, but the combination of direct searches at the CERN e + e − Collider (LEP) [1] and precision measurements of electroweak parameters constrain m H to 1 Visitor from Augustana College, Sioux Falls, SD, USA.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: 2 Visitor from The University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: 3 Visitor from SLAC, Menlo Park, CA, USA.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: 4 Visitor from ICREA/IFAE, Barcelona, Spain.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: 5 Visitor from Centro de Investigacion en Computacion -IPN, Mexico City, Mexico.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: 6 Visitor from ECFM, Universidad Autonoma de Sinaloa, Culiacán, Mexico.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: 7 Visitor from Universität Bern, Bern, Switzerland.
body_text.section: Tevatron Standard Model Higgs boson Electroweak symmetry breaking

body_text.text: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

. While the region 158 < m H < 175 GeV has been excluded at the 95% CL by a combination of searches at CDF and D0 [3][4][5][6], the remaining mass range continues to be probed at the Fermilab Tevatron Collider. The associated production of a Higgs boson and a leptonically-decaying W boson is among the cleanest Higgs boson search channels at the Tevatron, and provides the largest usable event yield for the decay H → bb in the range m H < 135 GeV. Several searches for W H production at a pp center-of-mass energy of √ s = 1.96 TeV have been published. Three of these [7][8][9] use subsamples (0.17 fb −1 , 0.44 fb −1 , and 1.1 fb −1 ) of the data analyzed in this Letter, while three from the CDF Collaboration are based on cumulative samples (0.32 fb −1 , 0.95 fb −1 and 2.7 fb −1 ) of integrated luminosity [10][11][12]. We present a new search using an improved multivariate technique, in 5.3 fb −1 of integrated luminosity collected by the D0 detector. The search selects events with one charged lepton ( = electron, e, or muon, μ), an imbalance in transverse energy (/ E T ) that arises from the unobserved neutrino in the W → ν decay, and either two or three jets, with one or two of these selected as candidate b-quark jets (b-tagged).
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The channels are separated into independent categories based on the number of b-tagged jets in an event (one or two).
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Single b-tagged events contain three important sources of backgrounds:
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: (i) multijet events, where a jet is misidentified as an isolated lepton,
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: (ii) W boson production in association with c-quark or lightquark jets, and
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: (iii) W boson production in association with two heavy-flavor (bb, cc) jets.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: In events with two b-tagged jets, the dominant backgrounds are from W bb, tt, and single top-quark production.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The analysis relies on the following components of the D0 detector [13]:
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: (i) a central-tracking system, which consists of a silicon microstrip tracker (SMT) and a central fiber tracker (CFT), both located within a 2 T superconducting solenoidal magnet;
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: (ii) a liquid-argon/uranium calorimeter containing electromagnetic, fine hadronic, and coarse hadronic layers, segmented into a central section (CC), covering pseudorapidity |η| < 1.1 relative to the center of the detector [14], and two end calorimeters (EC) extending coverage to |η| ≈ 4.0, all housed in separate cryostats [15], with scintillators between the CC and EC cryostats providing sampling of developing showers for 1.1 < |η| < 1.4;
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: (iii) a muon system located beyond the calorimetry consisting of layers of tracking detectors and scintillation trigger counters, one before and two after the 1.8 T iron toroids.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: A 2006 upgrade of the D0 detector added an inner layer of silicon [16] to the SMT and an improved calorimeter trigger [17].
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The integrated luminosity is measured using plastic scintillator arrays located in front of the EC cryostats at 2.7 < |η| < 4.4.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The trigger and data acquisition systems are designed to accommodate high instantaneous luminosities.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Events in the electron channel are triggered by a logical OR of several triggers that require an electromagnetic (EM) object or an EM object in conjunction with a jet.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Trigger efficiencies are taken into account in the Monte Carlo (MC) simulation through a weighting of events based on an efficiency derived from data, and parametrized as a function of electron η and azimuth φ, and jet transverse momentum p T .
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: We accept events for the muon channel from an inclusive mixture of single high-p T muon, jet and muon plus jet triggers.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: This inclusive trigger approach provides a gain in efficiency relative to the single muon triggers alone.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: We validate it by comparing events passed by the single muon triggers and find good agreement between data and MC.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Events not selected by the single muon trigger are selected by complementary triggers, typically jet triggers.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The efficiency of the complementary triggers is modeled as a function of the scalar sum of the p T of jets (H T ) in an event, and is used to weight the MC.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: We find good agreement between data and MC when combining the single muon and complementary triggers to form the inclusive trigger set.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The leading-order (LO) pythia [18] MC generator is used to simulate production of dibosons (W W , W Z, and Z Z ) with inclusive decays, W H → lνbb and Z H → llbb (l = e, μ, or τ ).
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The contribution from Z H events (in which one lepton is not identified) to the total signal corresponds to approximately 5%.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Background from W /Z (V ) + jets and tt events is generated with alpgen [19], interfaced to pythia for parton showering and hadronization.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The alpgen samples are produced in the leading logarithm approximation with the MLM parton-jet matching prescription [19].
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The V + jets samples are divided into V + light jets and V + heavyflavor jets.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The V + light jets samples include V jj, V bj, and V cj processes, where j is a light-flavor (u, d or s quark or a gluon) jet, while the V + heavy-flavor samples for V bb and V cc are generated separately.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Single top-quark events are generated using comphep [20,21] at next-to-leading order (NLO), with pythia used for parton evolution and hadronization.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Simulation of both background and signal processes relies on the CTEQ6L1 [22] LO parton distribution functions for all MC events.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: These events are processed through the full D0 detector simulation based on geant [23], and use the same reconstruction software as used for D0 data.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Events from randomly chosen beam crossings with the same instantaneous luminosity profile as the data are overlaid on the simulated events to reproduce the effect of multiple pp interactions and detector noise.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]
< m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The signal cross sections and branching fractions are calculated at next-to-next-to-leading order (NNLO) and are taken from Refs.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: [25][26][27][28][29], while the tt, single t, and diboson cross sections are at NLO, and taken from Refs.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: [30,31], and the mcfm program, respectively.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: As a cross check, we compare data with the alpgen prediction for W + jets, corrected in such a way that the inclusive W production cross section is equal to its NNLO calculation [32] with MRST2004 NNLO PDFs [33], and we find a relative data/MC normalization factor of 1.0 ± 0.1 for W (at least two jets), where all background contributions other than W + jets were first subtracted from data.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Based on the fractions of data events with 0, 1, or 2 b-tagged jets [34], we also observe good agreement with our prediction for the fraction of W bb and W cc in The / E T is calculated from the individual calorimeter cells in the EM and fine hadronic layers of the calorimeter, and is corrected for the presence of muons.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: All energy corrections to electrons and jets (including energy in the coarse-hadronic layers associated with jets) are propagated into the / E T .
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: To suppress multijet background, Lepton candidates are identified in two steps.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: First, each candidate must pass "loose" identification criteria.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: For electrons, we require 95% of the energy in a shower to be deposited in the EM section of the calorimeter (isolation from other calorimeter energy depositions), spatial distributions of calorimeter energies consistent with those expected for EM showers, and a reconstructed track matched to the EM shower, but isolated from other tracks.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: A "loose" muon is defined by hits in each layer of the muon system, scintillator hits in time with a beam crossing (to veto cosmic rays), a spatial match with a track in the central tracker, and isolation relative to jet axies ( R > 0.5) [14] to reject semileptonic decays of hadrons.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: In the second step, the loose leptons are subjected to a more restrictive "tight" selection.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Tight electrons must satisfy more restrictive calorimeter isolation and EM energy-fraction criteria, and satisfy a likelihood test developed on Z → ee data based on eight quantities characterizing the EM nature of different particle interactions [37].
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Tight muons must satisfy more strict isolation criteria on energy in the calorimeter and on momenta of tracks near trajectories of muon candidates.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Inefficiencies introduced by lepton-identification and isolation criteria are determined from Z → data.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The final selections for signal rely on events with only tight leptons, and events with loose leptons but not tight leptons are used to determine the multijet background.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Jets are reconstructed using a midpoint cone algorithm [38] with radius 0.5.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Identification requirements for jets are based on longitudinal and transverse shower profiles, and minimize the possibility that the jets are caused by noise or spurious depositions of energy.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: For data taken after the upgrade in 2006, we require that jets in data and in the corresponding simulation have at least two associated tracks emanating from the reconstructed pp interaction vertex.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The parameters for jet-identification efficiency, energy calibration, and energy resolution are adjusted accordingly in the simulation to match the data.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Also, comparison of alpgen with other generators and with data shows small discrepancies in distributions of jet pseudorapidity and dijet angular separations [39].
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The data are therefore used to correct the alpgen W + jets and Z + jets MC events through polynomial reweighting functions, parameterized by the leading and second-leading jet η, and R between the two jets of highest p T , that bring these distributions for the total simulated background and in the high-statistics sample of events prior to b-tagging into agreement.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Instrumental background and that from semileptonic decays of hadrons, referred to jointly as the multijet background, are estimated from data.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The instrumental background is significant in the electron channel, where a jet with a high EM fraction can pass electron-identification criteria, or a photon can be misidentified as an electron.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: In the muon channel, the multijet background is less important and arises mainly from semileptonic decay of heavyflavor quarks, where the muon passes isolation criteria.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: To estimate the number of events that contain a jet that passes "tight" lepton selection, we determine the probability f T |L for a "loose" lepton candidate, originating from a jet, to also pass tight identification.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: This is done in events that pass preselection requirements before applying the selection on M W T , i.e., events that contain one loose lepton and two jets, but small / E T (5-15 GeV).
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The total non-multijet background is estimated from MC and subtracted from the data before estimating the contribution from multijet events.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Summary of event yields for the + b-tagged jets + / E T final state.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Event yields in data are compared with the expected number of ST and DT events in the samples with W boson candidates plus two or three jets, comprised of contributions from simulated diboson pairs (labeled "W Z" in the table), W /Z + bb or cc ("W bb"), W /Z + light-quark jets ("W + lf "), and top-quark ("tt" and "Single t") production, as well as data-derived multijet background ("MJ").
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The quoted uncertainties include both statistical and systematic contributions, including correlations between background sources and channels.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: for identifying heavy-flavored jets is based on a combination of seven variables sensitive to the presence of tracks or secondary vertices displaced significantly from the primary vertex.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: All tagging efficiencies are determined separately for data and for simulated events.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: We first use a low threshold on the NN output that corresponds to a rate of 2.7% for light-flavor jets of p T 50 GeV that are mistakenly tagged as heavy-flavored jets.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: If two jets in an event pass this b-tagging requirement, the event is classified as doubleb-tagged (DT).
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Events that are not classified as DT are considered for placement in an independent single-b-tag (ST) sample, which requires exactly one jet to satisfy a more restrictive NN operating point corresponding to a misidentification rate of 0.9%.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The efficiencies for identifying a jet that contains a b hadron for the two NN operating points are (63 ± 1)% and (53 ± 1)%, respectively, for a jet with a p T of 50 GeV.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: These efficiencies are determined for "taggable" jets, i.e., jets with at least two tracks, each with at least one hit in the SMT.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Simulated events are corrected to have the same fraction of jets satisfying the taggability and b-tagging requirements as found in preselected data.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The expected event yields following these selection criteria for specific backgrounds and for m H = 115 GeV are compared to the observed number of events in Table 1. Distributions in dijet invariant mass for the two jets of highest p T , in 2-jet and 3-jet events are shown for the ST and DT samples in Figs. 1(a) We use a random forest (RF) multivariate technique [41,42] to separate the SM background from signal, and search for an excess, which is expected primarily at large values of RF discriminant.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: A separate RF discriminant is used for each combination of jet multiplicity (two or three), lepton flavor (e or μ), and number of b-tagged jets (one or two).
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The 2-jet events are divided into datataking periods, before and after the 2006 detector upgrade, for a total of twelve separately trained RFs for each chosen Higgs boson mass.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: Each RF consists of a collection of individual decision trees, with each tree considering a random subset of the twenty kinematic and topological input variables listed in Table 2. The final RF output is the average over the individual trees.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The input variables √ŝ and R(dijet, +ν) each have two solutions arising from the two possibilities for the longitudinal neutrino momentum, assuming the lepton and / E T (ν) constitute the decay products of an on-shell W boson.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: The angles θ * and χ are described in Ref.
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

body_text.text: [43], and exploit kinematic differences arising from the scalar nature of
body_text.section: < m H < 185 GeV at the 95% CL [2]

List of RF input variables, where j 1 ( j 2 ) refers to the jet with the highest (second highest) p T .

body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: φ between lepton and leading jet  [8].
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: However, the gain in sensitivity using the RF output as the final discriminant is about 20% for a Higgs mass of 115 GeV, which, in terms of the expected limit on the W H cross section, is equivalent to a gain of about 40% in integrated luminosity.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainties that affect the signal and SM backgrounds can be categorized by the nature of their source, i.e., theoretical (e.g., uncertainty on a cross section), MC modeling (e.g., reweighting of alpgen samples), or experimental (e.g., uncertainty on integrated luminosity).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Some of these uncertainties affect only the normalization of the signal or backgrounds, while others also affect the differential distribution of the RF output.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Theoretical uncertainties include uncertainties on the tt and single top-quark production cross sections (10% and 12%, respectively [30,31]), an uncertainty on the diboson production cross section (6% [24]), and an uncertainty on W + heavy-flavor production (20%, estimated from mcfm).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: These uncertainties affect only the normalization of the backgrounds.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Uncertainties from modeling that affect the distribution in the RF output include uncertainties on trigger efficiency as derived from data (3-5%), lepton identification and reconstruction efficiency (5-6%), reweighting of alpgen MC samples (2%), the MLM matching applied to W /Z + light-jet events (<0.5%), and the systematic uncertainties associated with choice of renormalization and factorization scales in alpgen as well as the uncertainty on the strong coupling constant (2%).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Uncertainties on the alpgen renormalization and factorization scales are evaluated by adjusting the nominal scale for each, simultaneously, by a factor of 0.5 and 2.0.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Experimental uncertainties that affect only the normalization of the signal and SM backgrounds arise from the uncertainty on  uncertainties.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The lightly-shaded region represents the total systematic uncertainty before using constraints from data (referred to as "Pre-Fit" in the legend), while the solid lines represent the total systematic uncertainty after constraining with data ("Post-Fit" in the legend).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The darker shaded region represents the SM Higgs signal expectation scaled up by a factor of 5.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: integrated luminosity (6.1%) [46].
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Those that also affect the distribution in RF output include jet taggability (3%), b-tagging efficiency (2.5-3% per heavy quark-jet), the light-quark jet misidentification rate (10%), acceptance for jet identification (5%); jet-energy calibration and resolution (varies between 15% and 30%, depending on the process and channel).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Model in multijet background is limited by the statistical uncertainty of data after tagging (10-20%), which also covers the uncertainty in the flavor dependence of f T |L .
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The background-subtracted data points for the RF discriminant for m H = 115 GeV, with all channels combined, are shown with their systematic uncertainties in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: We observe no excess relative to expectation from SM background, and we set upper limits on the production cross section σ (W H) using the RF outputs from all the channels.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The binning of the RF output is adjusted to assure adequate population of background events in each bin.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: We calculate all limits at the 95% CL using a modified frequentist approach and a Poisson log-likelihood ratio as test statistic [47,48].
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The likelihood ratio is studied using pseudoexperiments based on randomly drawn Poisson trials of signal and background events.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: We treat systematic uncertainties as "nuisance parameters" constrained by their priors, and the best fits of these parameters to data are determined at each value of m H by maximizing the likelihood ratio [49].
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: Independent fits are performed to the background-only and signal-plus-background hypotheses.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: All appropriate correlations of systematic uncertainties are maintained among channels and between signal and background.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainties before and after fitting are indicated in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The log-likelihood ratios for the backgroundonly model and the signal-plus-background model as a function of m H are shown in Fig. 3(a).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The upper limit on σ (pp → W H) × B(H → bb) at the 95% CL is a factor of 4.5 larger than the SM expectation for m H = 115 GeV, and the corresponding expected upper limit is 4.8.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The analysis is repeated for ten other m H values from 100 to 150 GeV; the corresponding observed and expected 95% CL limits relative to their SM expectations are given in Table 3 and in Fig. 3(b).
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: In conclusion, + / E T + 2 or 3-jet events have been analyzed in a search for W H production in 5.3 fb −1 of pp collisions at the Fermilab Tevatron.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The yield of single and double b-tagged jets in these events is in agreement with the expected background.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: We have applied a Random Forest multivariate analysis technique to further separate signal and background.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: We have set upper limits on σ (pp → W H) × B(H → bb) relative to their SM expectation for Higgs masses between 100 and 150 GeV.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: For m H = 115 GeV, the observed (expected) 95% CL limit is a factor of 4.5 (4.8) larger than the SM expectation.
body_text.section: Variable Definition

body_text.text: The data are adequately described by the sum of the simulated SM processes and multijet background.
The contributions expected from a Higgs boson with m H = 115 GeV, multiplied by a factor of ten, are also shown for comparison.

body_text.section: Fig. 3 .

body_text.text: Preselected events are also required to have / E T > 20 GeV, either two or three jets with p T > 20 GeV (after correcting jet energies[35]) and |η| < 2.5, and H T > 60 GeV for 2-jet events, or H T > 80 GeV for 3-jet events.
This analysis is based on a preselection of events with an electron of p T > 15 GeV, with |η| < 1.1 or 1.5 < |η| < 2.5, or a muon of p T > 15 GeV, with |η| < 1.6.
is the transverse mass of the W boson candidate.

Events that contain additional charged leptons isolated from jets, with the lepton passing the flavor-dependent p T thresholds p e T > 15 GeV, p μ T > 10 GeV, and p τ T > 10 or 15 GeV depending on τ decay channel [36], are rejected to decrease dilepton background from Z boson and tt events.
Events must have a reconstructed pp interaction vertex (containing at least three associated tracks) that is located within ±40 cm of the center of the detector in the longitudinal direction.
For electrons, f T |L is determined as a function of electron p T in three regions of |η| and four of φ(/ E T , e), while for muons it is taken as a function of |η| for two regions of φ(/ E T , μ).
The efficiency for a loose lepton to pass the tight identification (ε T |L ) is measured in Z → events in data, and is modeled as a function of p T for electrons and muons.
The estimation of multijet background described in Ref.
[37] is used to determine the multijet background directly from data, where each event is assigned a weight that contributes to the multijet estimation based
on f T |L and ε T |L as a function of event kinematics.
Since f T |L depends on / E T , the scale of this estimate of the multijet background must be adjusted when comparing to data with / E T > 20 GeV.

Before applying b-tagging, we fit the background templates to the data M W T distribution to obtain the normalizations for the multijet and W + jets backgrounds simultaneously.Efficient identification of b jets is central to the search for W H production.
The D0 neural network (NN) b-tagging algorithm[40]
